content.description: An easy mixed route that leads to steeper smearing for the finish. Shares anchor with Eskimo Joe.
content.location: To the right of Battle of the Bulge. Gully/corner climb.

content.description: Probably the best route at the crag. Stout climbing after the first bolt. Make sure you know how to stem, crimp, and smear. You'll be relying heavily on your feel for this one. Crux is between the second and third bolt. Shares the same anchor as Ants on a Log and Ants Traverse.
content.location: Just above the ledge just left of where the staircase starts.

content.description: Honestly, I would grade this around the 8+ range. Easy climbing up the pillar, but the high step onto the slab is scary.
content.location: On the North Facing wall in the corridor. Look for the pillar.

content.description: You can protect this, I suppose, but why bother? The rock quality is less than stellar, that said, judicious hold selection should make this reasonably safe. Caveat Emptor.This was established as a free solo, so, in order to preserve the experience of the first ascensionists,  it must foreveraftermore be climbed in said fashion. For the most authentic experience you should climb it barefooted. That said, if you choose to break with convention, then you'll just have to work out the pro for yourself. It should be obvious.There are no anchors at the top, but you can easily walk off to climber's R and return by following the white dots up and around returning to the top of the staircase.
content.location: The face between Staircase Crack Left and Staircase Crack R

content.description: Follow the obvious line.This was established as a free solo, so, in order to preserve the experience of the first ascensionists,  it must foreveraftermore be climbed in said fashion. For the most authentic experience you should climb it barefooted. That said, if you choose to break with convention, then you'll just have to work out the pro for yourself. It should be obvious.There are no anchors at the top, but you can easily walk off to climber's R and return by following the white dots up and around returning to the top of the staircase.
content.location: Ascend the namesake staircase and exit L at step #22. The obvious, fat crack to climber's R. You can't miss it.

content.description: You can climb this a number of ways, but stick with the crack(s) for the best experience. This was established as a free solo, so, in order to preserve the experience of the first ascensionists,  it must foreveraftermore be climbed in said fashion. For the most authentic experience you should climb it barefooted. That said, if you choose to break with convention, then you'll just have to work out the pro for yourself. It should be obvious.There are no anchors at the top, but you can easily walk off to climber's R and return by following the white dots up and around returning to the top of the staircase.
content.protection: Lots of fatties, but why bother?
content.location: Ascend the namesake staircase and exit L at step #22. The obvious, fat crack to climber's L. You can't miss it.

content.description: Similar climbing to Eskimo Joe but slightly harder finish. Trust your feet. Watch your chalk bag when coming down it'll flip upside down and empty out
content.location: To right right of Eskimo Joe, behind the Oak Tree.

climbs.name: Great White
climbs.fa: Kevin Keith, Josh Bradley and Stephanie Griffin 11/08/13

content.description: Super clean and fun climbing on steep in cut holds.
content.protection: 5 or 6 bolts and a bolted anchor
content.location: Furthest west or left route on the wall with bolts.

content.description: Granite smearing. crux is at the top.
content.location: To the right of Yesterday, just in front of the Oak tree.

content.description: Shares the same start as Deja Vu. Slappy granite style climbing that requires you to trust your feet. Continue straight up after 3rd bolt. shares the same anchor as Deja Vu. As with all the climbs in this area you can set up a top-rope.
content.location: Same start as Deja Vu. Just to the right of the Oak tree.

content.description: Another granite slab climb but just a little harder, probably why it's called Deja Vu. Shares the same start and anchors as Deja Vu Direct Exit. But go to the left after second to last bolt.
content.location: just left of the large Oak tree.

climbs.name: Battle of the Bulge
climbs.fa: Josh Bradley, Steph Griffin and Kevin Keith

content.description: Face climb past three bolts until you reach the bulge with a crack. Go up and over the bulge using the crack or go around right for an easier exit. Shares the same bolted anchor with Great White.
content.protection: 3 bolts plus gear to medium size
content.location: Just to the right of Great White

content.description: Start on Ants on a Log, climb passed third bolt then move out left to connect with 4 bolt of Working Class Hero. Continue up and right of the finish of Working Class Hero, Shares the Anchor.
content.location: Last bolted line to the far right near the staircase.

content.description: Follow the bolts up the face of the arete.
content.location: Just right of Working Class Hero. last bolted line to the far right near the staircase. Look for the ledge.

content.description: Slab climb past a bulge. Make sure you have good feet. Holds are there where you need them. Shares the same Anchor as Deja Vu.
content.location: Just to the right of start of Deja Vu. Look for the bulge.

content.description: This is one of the more popular newer climbing areas in the Granite Dells. Shady Grove is a shady little area with mainly south facing routes in a group of trees above a pond on Granite Creek. The majority of the routes are bolt protected. The approach and accessibility make this a fun outing. Please be respectful of the people living across the pond. No rock throwing below into the water, there are wood ducks nesting below. Thanks
